February 1, 2009: Fiction
PLUM SPOOKY, by Janet Evanovich. (St. Martin’s, $27.95.) The bounty hunter
Stephanie Plum hunts an evil genius and his sidekick, who are hiding in New
Jersey’s Pine Barrens.
THE HOST, by Stephenie Meyer. (Little, Brown, $25.99.) Aliens have taken
control of the minds and bodies of most human beings, but one woman won’t
surrender.
BLACK OPS, by W. E.B. Griffin. (Putnam, $26.95.) An Army officer and special
presidential agent is targeted for death — but by whom?
MOUNTING FEARS, by Stuart Woods. (Putnam, $25.95.) In the weeks before an
election, a president must deal with crises ranging fom loose nukes in Pakistan to
the reappearance of a rogue C.I.A. agent to a threatened sex scandal.
THE STORY OF EDGAR SAWTELLE, by David Wroblewski. (Ecco, $25.95.) A
young mute who can communicate with the dogs his family raises takes refuge
with three of them in the Wisconsin woods after his father’s death.
SCARPETTA, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $27.95.) The forensic pathologist
Kay Scarpetta takes on a new assignment in New York.
CROSS COUNTRY, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) Alex Cross
chases the leader of a lethal teenage gang.
THE GUERNSEY LITERARY AND POTATO PEEL PIE SOCIETY, by Mary Ann
Shaffer and Annie Barrows. (Dial, $22.) A journalist travels to the island of
Guernsey to meet residents who resisted the Nazi occupation.
FIRE AND ICE, by Julie Garwood. (Ballantine, $26.) A reporter and her bodyguard
uncover a conspiracy in Alaska.
THE HOUR I FIRST BELIEVED, by Wally Lamb. (Harper, $29.95.) A man
reconstructs five generations of family history.
THE PIANO TEACHER, by Janice Y. K. Lee. (Viking, $25.95.) An Englishwoman
in 1950s Hong Kong discovers devastating secrets from the years of the Japanese
occupation.
FROM DEAD TO WORSE, by Charlaine Harris. (ACE, $24.95.) Following a
deadly explosion at a vampire summit, the cocktail waitress Sookie Stackhouse
faces danger.
ECLIPSE, by Richard North Patterson. (Holt, $26.) A San Francisco lawyer agrees
to defend a Nigerian reformer whose wife he loved in college.
BEAT THE REAPER, by Josh Bazell. (Little, Brown, $24.99.) A former hit man for
February 1, 2009
Non-Fiction
OUTLIERS, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) Why some people
succeed — it has to do with luck and opportunity — from the author of “Blink” and
“The Tipping Point.”
GUILTY, by Ann Coulter. (Crown Forum, $27.95.) The columnist argues that
liberals victimize everyone else by pretending to be victims themselves.
DEWEY, by Vicki Myron with Bret Witter. (Grand Central, $19.99.) The kitten left
freezing in the returned-book slot of an Iowa public library and his rise to fame.
TOO FAT TO FISH, by Artie Lange with Anthony Bozza. (Spiegel & Grau, $24.95.)
Humorous memories from the comedian, a member of the cast of “The Howard
Stern Show.”
AMERICAN LION, by Jon Meacham. (Random House, $30.) Andrew Jackson in
the White House, by Newsweek’s editor.
WHY WE SUCK, by Denis Leary. (Viking, $26.95.) Sardonic essays from the actor
and comedian.
THE AMERICAN JOURNEY OF BARACK OBAMA, by the editors of Life
magazine. (Little, Brown, $24.99.) Photographs and essays, starting with Obama’s
birth in Hawaii.
A BOLD FRESH PIECE OF HUMANITY, by Bill O’Reilly. (Broadway, $26.) The
Fox News commentator on his upbringing and career.
HOT, FLAT, AND CROWDED, by Thomas L. Friedman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux,
$27.95.) How a green revolution can renew America, by the New York Times
columnist.
THE ASCENT OF MONEY, by Niall Ferguson. (Penguin Press, $29.95.) A
financial history of the world.
MULTIPLE BLESSINGS, by Jon Gosselin, Kate Gosselin and Beth Carson.
(Zondervan, $19.) A couple has sextuplets.
WISHFUL DRINKING, by Carrie Fisher. (Simon & Schuster, $21.) A memoir
based on Fisher’s one-woman show.
THE INHERITANCE, by David E. Sanger. (Harmony, $26.95.) The foreign policy
challenges that George Bush left for President Obama, by a New York Times
correspondent.
THE RETURN OF DEPRESSION ECONOMICS AND THE CRISIS OF 2008, by
Paul Krugman. (Norton, $24.95.) The origins of the current financial crisis and how
it can be contained, by the Nobel Prize-winning economist.
